titleStmt.title: Description of Free Library of Philadelphia, Lewis E 112: Book of Hours, Use of Rome

msIdentifier.collection: John Frederick Lewis Collection of European Manuscripts

msContents.summary: This manuscript is an early sixteenth-century Book of Hours with a liturgical calendar for Lyon. It is generously illuminated, with twelve full-page miniatures, eighteen smaller miniatures, and illuminated initials. At least five leaves are missing from the manuscript.

msItem.title: Book of Hours, Use of Rome
Gospel lessons from Matthew and Mark (text missing)
Prayer
msItem.incipit: Benedictio dei patris omnipotentis cum angelis ... [fol. 9r]
msItem.explicit: Et salvum me fecit dextera tua. [fol. 9r]

msItem.title: Mixed Hours of the Virgin, Cross, and Holy Spirit

supportDesc.extent: i+105+i; 182 x 113 mm bound to 190 x 125 mm
supportDesc.foliation: Modern foliation in pencil, upper right recto

collation.p: Structure uncertain; at least seven missing leaves (at least one each between fols. 7 and 8, 13 and 14, 41 and 42, 45 and 46, 62 and 63, 79 and 80, and 98 and 99)

layoutDesc.layout: Twenty-one long lines; frame-ruled in faint ink; written area: 112 x 68 mm

decoDesc.decoNote: Twelve full-page miniatures with architectural borders; eighteen smaller miniatures; illuminated initials (one-line and two-line) and line fillers throughout
9vLarge miniature, male owner portrait with Virgin and Child and two angels in garden
21vLarge miniature, owner portraits with patron saints (a bishop and Saint Christopher)
22rLarge miniature, crowned Virgin and Child on a crescent moon
47rLarge miniature, Job with his wife and neighbors
48rLarge miniature, King David, Bathsheba, and the body of Uriah
50rSmall miniature, King David and angel with flaming sword
52rSmall miniature, King David with dead infant son
55vSmall miniature, King David and the dead Absalom
86rLarge miniature, Saint Bridget praying before the Cross

binding.p: Original brown calf covers over wooden boards; blind stamped including emblems of the Virgin and Child on a crescent, the Pascal Lamb, and Saint Matthew; bound at the Benedictine Abbey of St. Mathias at Trèves (de Ricci); rebacked

history.provenance: Coat of arms of the family de Farges d'Espeisse of Auvergne, originally from Lyon (argent a chevron azure charged with five estoiles or surmounted by a crescent argent; fol. 21v); second coat of arms of the former on the dexter side dimidiated with Legoué, of Mayenne on the sinister (argent a bend gules charged with three unicorn heads or; also fol. 21v); Laurent Campagne (16th century); Ambrose Firmin-Didot (gilt leather bookplate inside front cover, sold 1884); Thomas Richardson, Boston (stamp in blue ink, front flyleaf recto); John Frederick Lewis, Philadelphia, 1919 (inscription in ink, front flyleaf recto); given by his widow, Anne Baker Lewis, to the Free Library of Philadelphia in 1936.
